Introduction

Esophagitis refers to inflammation of the esophageal mucosa, with various etiologies including acid reflux, infections, and medication-induced injury.  The clinical course varies depending on the underlying cause, and complications can include strictures or perforation.

Pathophysiology and clinical presentation

The pathogenesis and clinical presentation of esophagitis depend on the underlying etiology.  Eosinophilic esophagitis (discussed in a separate article) is another important type of esophagitis, typically associated with atopic conditions and presenting with dysphagia and food impaction.

Reflux esophagitis

Chronic exposure of the esophageal epithelium to gastric acid leads to mucosal injury, resulting in erosive changes and, over time, complications such as strictures or Barrett esophagus.  Risk factors for gastroesophageal reflex disease (GERD) include obesity, hiatal hernia, and dietary habits (eg, excessive fatty foods, alcohol) that predispose to reflux.  Symptoms of reflux esophagitis include heartburn, retrosternal pain, and dysphagia.  Odynophagia (ie, painful swallowing) is not typical.

Infectious esophagitis

Esophageal infection is typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, including HIV/AIDS (particularly CD4 <100 cells/mmÂ³), posttransplant immunosuppression, and chronic steroid use.  Classic organisms include:

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV):  HSV invades the esophageal mucosa, causing small, vesicular lesions that evolve into "punched-out" ulcers with distinct borders.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV):  CMV targets endothelial cells, producing large, linear or longitudinal ulcers, often in the distal esophagus.
  • Candida albicans:  Fungal overgrowth leads to white, pseudomembranous plaques on the esophageal lining.

Common symptoms include dysphagia and retrosternal pain.  Unlike reflux esophagitis, patients with infectious esophagitis often experience fever and odynophagia (most painful in HSV and least painful with C albicans).  Candidal esophagitis is usually accompanied by oral thrush, although this may be absent in up to 18% of cases.

Pill-induced esophagitis

Pill-induced esophagitis occurs due to direct caustic injury from adherence of certain medications to the esophageal lining.  Common medications include tetracyclines, bisphosphonates, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and potassium chloride.  The risk of pill-induced esophagitis is increased by inadequate fluid intake, lying down soon after ingestion, or esophageal anatomic abnormalities (eg, compression from the aortic arch or carina).  The usual presentation is the sudden onset of severe retrosternal pain and odynophagia starting after medication ingestion, ranging from hours to days after.

Diagnosis

The gold standard for diagnosing esophagitis is an upper endoscopy with biopsies, but these procedures are not always necessary.

Infectious esophagitis

In patients with a high suspicion of infectious esophagitis (eg, fever or severe immunocompromise), urgent endoscopy is typically warranted.  A notable exception is patients with thrush who have a high likelihood of candidal esophagitis.  In such cases, an empiric trial of fluconazole can be given; if symptoms do not improve after 3 days, endoscopy should be performed.  Endoscopic and histologic findings for infectious esophagitis include:

  • HSV:  Small, deep, well-demarcated ("punched-out") ulcers (

    ).  Multinucleated giant cells and Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusions (

    ).
  • CMV:  Large, linear or longitudinal ulcers, often in the lower esophagus.  Enlarged cells with intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions ("owl's eye") (
    image 3
    ).
  • Candida:  White, cottage cheeseâ€“like plaques, due to yeasts and pseudohyphae infiltrating the mucosa (

Reflux esophagitis

In patients suspected of having reflux esophagitis, an empiric trial of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) can be initiated.  If the patient is already on a PPI and symptoms persist, an endoscopy is indicated.  Typical endoscopic findings in reflux esophagitis include irregular or linear erosions, predominantly in the distal esophagus.

Pill-induced esophagitis

If pill-induced esophagitis is suspected, discontinuing the offending medication and closely monitoring the patient may suffice.  Endoscopic evaluation is recommended for those with severe or atypical symptoms (eg, hematemesis, persistent abdominal pain) or if symptoms fail to resolve within 1 week after stopping the causative agent.

Differential diagnosis

Esophagitis should be differentiated from other causes of esophageal symptoms.  Patients with retrosternal chest pain without dysphagia should be evaluated for cardiopulmonary etiologies (eg, angina, pulmonary embolism).  Esophageal conditions that may mimic esophagitis include:

  • Motility disorders:  Conditions such as achalasia, diffuse esophageal spasm, and nutcracker esophagus may present similarly with dysphagia, although odynophagia is not typical; diagnosis involves a barium swallow study or manometry testing.
  • Structural abnormalities:  Esophageal strictures or rings (eg, Schatzki ring), or esophageal tumors can cause progressive dysphagia; odynophagia is uncommon unless associated mucosal inflammation or ulceration is found.

In addition to upper endoscopy, these esophageal conditions can be differentiated with barium swallow studies and esophageal manometry.

Management

Treatment is tailored to the underlying cause.

Reflux esophagitis

  • Lifestyle modifications (eg, weight loss, head-of-bed elevation).
  • Acid suppression with a PPI (eg, omeprazole).

Infectious esophagitis

  • HSV:  Acyclovir is the treatment of choice.
  • CMV:  Ganciclovir or valganciclovir are effective.
  • Candida:  Systemic antifungal therapy with fluconazole is first-line, typically given orally rather than intravenously unless severe pain precludes oral administration.  Topical agents (eg, nystatin) should not be used.  Azole medications are teratogenic during the first trimester of pregnancy; amphotericin B is recommended.

Pill-induced esophagitis

  • Discontinue or modify the offending medication.
  • Instruct patients to remain upright and drink adequate water with pills.
  • Consider a short course of PPIs for symptomatic relief.

Summary

Esophagitis involves inflammation of the esophageal lining arising from various causes, including acid reflux, infections (often in immunocompromised patients), or direct injury from certain medications.  Clinical presentations vary:  Reflux esophagitis typically causes heartburn, dysphagia, and retrosternal pain, whereas infectious etiologies often feature odynophagia, fever, andâ€”especially with Candida albicansâ€”oral thrush.

Although endoscopy with biopsy is the diagnostic gold standard, it may be reserved for severe or refractory cases.  In many instances, such as presumed C albicans infection with thrush, suspected pill-induced damage, or uncomplicated reflux, an empiric trial of therapy (eg, fluconazole, discontinuation of the offending pill, or a proton pump inhibitor) can be attempted first, with endoscopy considered only if symptoms persist.  Treatment is guided by the underlying cause, ranging from acid suppression for reflux to antifungals, antivirals, or medication adjustments as needed.
